liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Lidia Thorpe has not travelled to parliament this week on doctor's orders, after being involved in a minor car accident late last week. Thorpe is recovering from whiplash and bruising after she was was rear-ended while in a parked car in Melbourne. Her office tells AAP she is "in pain but is alright". Thorpe has previously raised concerns about her safety and has had some formal protection. She is expected to return to parliament next week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Lidia Thorpe suffers minor injuries in a car crash

props.alt: A woman with dark hair, a black and white dress and green earrings stands in front of the Aboriginal flag

children.content: Senator Lidia Thorpe has minor injuries
(ABC News)
Senator Lidia Thorpe has not travelled to parliament this week on doctor's orders, after being involved in a minor car accident late last week.
Thorpe is recovering from whiplash and bruising after
she was was rear-ended while in a parked car
in Melbourne.
Her office tells AAP she is "in pain but is alright".
Thorpe has previously raised concerns about her safety and has had some formal protection.
She is expected to return to parliament next week.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A French military transport plane carrying 262 Europeans has arrived in Paris, in the first evacuation flight since mutinous soldiers ousted Niger's democratically elected president and shut its borders. France, Italy and Spain have all announced evacuations from Niger for their citizens and other European nationals, concerned that they risked becoming trapped by the coup. The Associated Press says about 600 French nationals want to leave, along with 400 people of other nationalities from Belgians to Danish, according to officials. The first flight carried mostly French nationals, and officials hope to finish the evacuation flights by today. With Niger's air space closed, France coordinated the evacuations with the regime that ousted the nation's leader, but without withdrawing its support for democratically elected President Mohamed Bazoum, diplomatic officials say. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Europeans begin evacuating from Niger, amid a military coup

featuredLink.title: Evacuations begin in Niger as neighbouring countries warn of war

children.content: Evacuees arrive at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris
(Reuters : Stephanie Lecocq)
A French military transport plane carrying
262 Europeans
has arrived in Paris, in the first evacuation flight since mutinous soldiers ousted Niger's democratically elected president and shut its borders.
France, Italy and Spain have all announced evacuations from Niger for their citizens and other European nationals, concerned that they risked becoming trapped
by the coup.
The Associated Press says about
600 French nationals
want to leave, along with
400 people of other nationalities
from Belgians to Danish, according to officials.

props.alt: People with bags standing and talking to each other near a large bus.

children.content: (AP: Sam Mednick)
The first flight carried mostly French nationals, and officials hope to finish the evacuation flights by today.

With Niger's air space closed, France coordinated the evacuations with the regime that ousted the nation's leader, but without withdrawing its support for democratically elected President Mohamed Bazoum, diplomatic officials say.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Poland's government says two Belarusian helicopters entered its airspace this morning — an incident which comes amid rising tensions along the NATO member's border with the Russian ally. Warsaw authorities say they will increase Poland's military presence along the border in response, and have summoned Belarus' top diplomat in Warsaw in protest. In a statement, Poland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs says it "communicated its firm opposition and called the Belarusian side to immediately explain the incident". "The Polish side underlined that the incident is considered as another element in escalating the tension at the Polish-Belarusian border," it says. "Poland expects Belarus to refrain from this type of activity." Anxieties have grown in Poland and in neighbouring Lithuania after mercenaries from the Russia-linked Wagner group arrived in Belarus following their short-lived rebellion against the Kremlin in June. You can read more background here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Poland says two Belarusian helicopters have violated its airspace

featuredLink.title: Poland sends troops to Belarus border fearing airspace violations

children.content: Poland's government says two Belarusian helicopters entered its airspace this morning — an incident which comes amid rising tensions along the NATO member's border with the Russian ally.
Warsaw authorities say
they will increase Poland's military presence along the border in response
, and have summoned Belarus' top diplomat in Warsaw in protest.
In a statement, Poland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs says it "communicated its firm opposition and called the Belarusian side to immediately explain the incident".
"The Polish side underlined that the incident is considered as another element in escalating the tension at the Polish-Belarusian border," it says.
"Poland expects Belarus to refrain from this type of activity."

Anxieties have grown in Poland and in neighbouring Lithuania after mercenaries from the Russia-linked Wagner group arrived in Belarus following their short-lived rebellion against the Kremlin in June.
You can read more background here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some. Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China. The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out is just 3 per cent from its record high. Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade. Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market. Top movers on ASX 200: BrainChip: +4% Pro Medicus: +2.6% Domino's Pizza: +2.1% Regis Resources: -4.3% AGL Energy: -4.1% Champion Iron: -3.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

children.content: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some.
Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China.
The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out is just 3 per cent from its record high.
Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade.
Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market.

BrainChip: +4%

Regis Resources: -4.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's unemployment rate climbed to a two-year high over the June quarter amid a rise in the number of people looking for work. While the labour market is tight, the jobless rate rose from 3.4 per cent to 3.6 per cent seasonally adjusted with 109,000 people out of work according to Statistics New Zealand. It says the labour force participation rate of 72.4 per cent and the employment rate of 69.8 per cent are the highest on record. The tourism industry drove the increase with employment returning to pre-COVID levels. Wages increased by 4.3 per cent over the year to June. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to leave official interest rates unchanged at 5.5 per cent this month. The country's economy is in recession which was triggered by the central bank's aggressive rate rise campaign. While New Zealand's jobless rate is at a two-year high, Australia's unemployment rate of 3.5 per cent, is near a 50-year low. New Zealand closed its borders from early 2020 to mid-2022 because of COVID-19, which drove down the unemployment rate because temporary migration was restricted.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand unemployment rate at two year high

children.content: New Zealand's unemployment rate climbed to a two-year high over the June quarter amid a rise in the number of people looking for work.
While the labour market is tight, the jobless rate rose from 3.4 per cent to 3.6 per cent seasonally adjusted with 109,000 people out of work according to Statistics New Zealand.

props.alt: Graph showing the NZ jobless rate

children.content: NZ jobless rate
(Statistics New Zealand )
It says the labour force participation rate of 72.4 per cent and the employment rate of 69.8 per cent are the highest on record.
The tourism industry drove the increase with employment returning to pre-COVID levels.
Wages increased by 4.3 per cent over the year to June.
The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to leave official interest rates unchanged at 5.5 per cent this month.
The country's economy is in recession which was triggered by the central bank's aggressive rate rise campaign.
While New Zealand's jobless rate is at a two-year high, Australia's unemployment rate of 3.5 per cent, is near a 50-year low.
New Zealand closed its borders from early 2020 to mid-2022 because of COVID-19, which drove down the unemployment rate because temporary migration was restricted.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rideshare firm Uber has swung from loss to profit for the second quarter of the financial year. Uber made a net profit of $US394 million ($596 million) from a net loss of $US2.6 billion ($3.9 billion) from the same quarter last year. Profit was boosted as its share market investments were revalued higher. Gross bookings rose by 16 per cent over the year to $US33.6 billion. On average, about 25 million trips a day were made on the platform from April to June, as travel recovered from the pandemic. Uber chief executive Dana Khoswoshahi said the company saw its first quarterly operating profit and its first quarter of free cash flow of more than $US1 billion. He says Uber is looking at further expanding into the travel market with flight, train and coach bookings available on its app. Mr Khoswoshahi says Uber is the rideshare leader in the majority of its international markets hitting record highs in Australia and Japan. However, its shares fell 5.7 per cent because its revenue of $US9.2 billion wasn't as good as expected by analysts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Uber makes second quarter profit

children.content: Rideshare firm Uber has swung from loss to profit for the second quarter of the financial year.
Uber made a net profit of $US394 million ($596 million) from a net loss of $US2.6 billion ($3.9 billion) from the same quarter last year.
Profit was boosted as its share market investments were revalued higher.
Gross bookings rose by 16 per cent over the year to $US33.6 billion.
On average, about 25 million trips a day were made on the platform from April to June, as travel recovered from the pandemic.
Uber chief executive Dana Khoswoshahi said the company saw its first quarterly operating profit and its first quarter of free cash flow of more than $US1 billion.
He says Uber is looking at further expanding into the travel market with flight, train and coach bookings available on its app.
Mr Khoswoshahi says Uber is the rideshare leader in the majority of its international markets hitting record highs in Australia and Japan.
However, its shares fell 5.7 per cent because its revenue of $US9.2 billion wasn't as good as expected by analysts.
